name: CodeDeployDeployApplication
description: Deploys an application to Amazon EC2 instance(s) using AWS CodeDeploy
author: Amazon Web Services
helpMarkDown:
Please refer to [AWS CodeDeploy User Guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/) for more information on working with AWS CodeDeploy.

More information on this task can be found in the [task reference](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vsts/latest/userguide/codedeploy-deployment.html).

####Task Permissions
This task requires permissions to call the following AWS service APIs (depending on selected task options, not all APIs may be used):
* codedeploy:GetApplication
* codedeploy:GetDeploymentGroup
* codedeploy:CreateDeployment
* codedeploy:GetDeployment

Depending on selected parameters the task may also require permissions to verify your deployment bundle exists in S3 or upload your application bundle to the specified Amazon S3 bucket. Depending on the size of the application bundle, either PutObject or the S3 multi-part upload APIs may be used.

inputs.name: awsCredentials
inputs.label: AWS Credentials
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies the AWS credentials to be used by the task in the build agent environment.

You can specify credentials using a service endpoint (of type _AWS_) in the task configuration or you can leave unspecified. If unspecified the task will attempt to obtain credentials from the following sources in order:

* From task variables named _AWS.AccessKeyID_, _AWS.SecretAccessKey_ and optionally _AWS.SessionToken_.
* From credentials set in environment variables in the build agent process. When using environment variables in the build agent process you may use the standard AWS environment variables: _AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_, _AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_ and optionally _AWS_SESSION_TOKEN_.
* If the build agent is running on an Amazon EC2 instance, from the instance metadata associated with the EC2 instance. For credentials to be available from EC2 instance metadata the instance must have been started with an instance profile referencing a role granting permissions to the task to make calls to AWS on your behalf. See [Using an IAM Role to Grant Permissions to Applications Running on Amazon EC2 Instances](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_use_switch-role-ec2.html) for more information.

inputs.name: regionName
inputs.label: AWS Region
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The AWS region code (us-east-1, us-west-2 etc) of the region containing the AWS resource(s) the task will use or create. For more information see [AWS Regions and Endpoints](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html).

If a region is not explicitly configured the task will attempt to obtain the region to be used from the following sources:

* From a task variable named _AWS.Region_.
* From the standard AWS environment variable _AWS_REGION_ in the build agent's environment.
*  If the build agent is running on an Amazon EC2 instance, from instance metadata associated with the EC2 instance.

__Note:__ The regions listed in the picker are those known at the time this software was released. New regions that are not listed may still be used by entering the _region code_ of the region (for example _us_west_2_).

inputs.name: applicationName
inputs.label: Application Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the AWS CodeDeploy application.

inputs.name: deploymentGroupName
inputs.label: Deployment Group Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the deployment group the revision is to be deployed to.

inputs.name: deploymentRevisionSource
inputs.label: Deployment Revision Source
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies the source of the revision to be deployed. You can select from:

**Folder or archive file in the workspace**: the task will create or use an existing zip archive in the location specified to *Revision Bundle*, upload the archive to Amazon S3 and supply the key of the S3 object to CodeDeploy as the revision source.

**Archive file in Amazon S3**: select to specify the key of an archive previously uploaded to Amazon S3 as the deployment revision source.

options.workspace: Folder or archive file in the workspace

inputs.name: revisionBundle
inputs.label: Revision Bundle
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The artifacts to be deployed.

You can supply a folder or a filename to this parameter. If a folder is supplied the task will zip the contents of the folder recursively into an archive file before uploading the archive to Amazon S3. If a filename is supplied the task uploads it, unmodified, to Amazon S3. Note that CodeDeploy requires the appspec.yml file describing the application to exist at the root of the specified folder or archive file.

inputs.name: bucketName
inputs.label: S3 Bucket Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the Amazon S3 bucket to which the revision bundle will be will be uploaded.

inputs.name: bundlePrefix
inputs.label: Target Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional folder (key prefix) for the uploaded revision bundle in the bucket. If not specified the bundle will be uploaded to the root of the bucket.

inputs.name: bundleKey
inputs.label: Revision Bundle Key
inputs.helpMarkDown: The Amazon S3 object key of the previously uploaded archive file containing the deployment revision artifacts.

inputs.name: fileExistsBehavior
inputs.label: Existing File Behavior
inputs.helpMarkDown: How AWS CodeDeploy should handle files that already exist in a deployment target location but weren't part of the previous successful deployment.

options.OVERWRITE: Overwrite the version already on the instance with the version in the new application revision
options.RETAIN: Keep the version already on the instance as part of the new deployment

inputs.name: updateOutdatedInstancesOnly
inputs.label: Update Outdated Instances Only
inputs.helpMarkDown: If checked deploys to only those instances that are not running the latest application revision.

inputs.name: ignoreApplicationStopFailures
inputs.label: Ignore Application Stop Failures
inputs.helpMarkDown: If checked then if the deployment causes the ApplicationStop deployment lifecycle event to an instance to fail, the deployment to that instance will not be considered to have failed at that point and will continue on to the BeforeInstall deployment lifecycle event.

inputs.name: timeoutInMins
inputs.label: Max Timeout (minutes)
inputs.helpMarkDown: Maximum time, specified in minutes, that the task should wait for the deployment to complete. By default a maximum of 30 minutes is used.

inputs.name: outputVariable
inputs.label: Output Variable
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the variable that will contain the deployment ID on task completion. The variable can be used as $(variableName) to refer to the function result in subsequent tasks.

inputs.name: logRequest
inputs.label: Log Request
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, request headers and other data for calls to AWS services are logged to the task's debug log.

inputs.name: logResponse
inputs.label: Log Response
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, the response metadata and body content of non-streaming responses from calls to AWS services are output to the task's debug log. The unique request ID, which can be useful when contacting AWS for support, is always logged to the task output regardless of this option setting.
